content:
Hi All!
Does anyone have some pointers on how to solve NNG lvl6 of the <= world?
Most levels before this went quite smoothly, but on this level it feels like I am not getting anywhere. I've searched for hints elsewhere online, but am surprised to find that even relatively recent posts related to the NNG (e.g. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5GkisJ0OImg ) show a version of the NNG of lean 4 that had a lot more intermediate worlds, and therefore more tactics unlocked before reaching this level. Therefore the solutions I find in these sources are unfortunately not usable.
Thanks a lot for any help!
PS: if anyone knows what happened to the removed 'intermediate' levels, such as the Function and Proposition worlds) I'd be quite curious to know that too!

I removed function and proposition world because feedback from users said that they were a bit weird and abstract, and in particular nothing to do with natural numbers. My initial motivation for putting them in was that I wanted to figure out how to teach intro, apply and exact and I thought that by introducing functions as in functional programming I could do this. But after a discussion with Patrick Massot he convinced me that it was possible to teach these tactics without ever introducing abstract types X and abstract propositions P (because this was what he was doing in his course in Orsay), and NNG4 shows he was right.

Re inequality world level 6 (antisymmetry): yeah, these levels are hard. Humans have such a geometric and intuitive understanding of inequalities, but the only tool you have is induction and its consequences. Here's a hint: replace the inequalities with equalities and then eliminate y from everything. Now look at the theorems you have already from earlier in this world.

Thank you, I got it now! Interesting how much it helps to know whether you're on the right track; previously I tried something similar but gave up much too quickly.
RE the removed levels: sounds very reasonable. I can imagine it can get quite abstract explaining more formal mathematics and functional programming at the same time. I, for one, don't really know what abstract types/propositions are. Do you (or anyone else who reads this) maybe have a recommendation for a (hopefully as fun as NNG4) resource to learn more about functional programming (in Lean)?
I learnt what little I know about functional programming from #tpil but isn't there even a book called something like functional programming in Lean??

As a mathematician I've never been too worried about the programming side of things, in fact the thing I enjoy about Lean the most is that I can write proofs without ever having to worry about running the corresponding functions or even thinking about them as functions or coding or anything like that.
Oh woops, there is! I'll take a look at both, thanks.
Thijs Vromen has marked this topic as resolved.
